basics.name: Akira Vernon
basics.label: Student
basics.summary: I am a junior in Computer Engineering at the University of Hawaii at Manoa. I expect to graduate in Spring, 2019 and hope to pursue a career in software development.

work.summary: Assisting the Hawaii Undergraduate Initiative (HUI) Program Coordinator through planning and administering workshops for students.
highlights: Maintained and built a community and support system of 400+ HUI students, alumni, and friends by providing on-campus resources to assist first-generation college students.
Managed the HUI Summer Program and HUI Registered Independent Organization’s meetings, fundraisers, socials, and other events.

work.position: Akamai Workforce Initiative Computer Engineering Intern
work.summary: Optimization of the Ray Tracing Algorithm for RPG (TMT AO Facility)
highlights: Developed a ray tracing program using C that reduces the effects of atmospheric distortion by using bilinear interpolation to reconstruct distorted wavefronts for the Reconstruction Parameter Generator used by the Adaptive Optics team.
Maximized performance and efficiency by using various directives from OpenMP API.
Conducted benchmarks of the ray tracing program with the Intel Xeon Phi 7210 CPU and other CPUs.

work.company: Hawaii Department of Education – Kaimuki High School and Washington Middle School
highlights: Assisted students in STEM courses, development of personal pride, and the successful completion of college eligibility requirements.
Served as a role model and mentor to at-risk students by being an example of personal excellence and high expectations.

volunteer.summary: Developer for firmware & algorithms of an autonomous robot
highlights: Developed a Micro-Mouse simulator in C.
Developing a modified maze-solving algorithm in C based on Flood fill algorithm.
Designed and developed a low-cost, accurate, and reliable environmental sensor module.
Tested computer to computer and computer to Arduino with Xbee shield communication.
Designed weather box housing using Google SketchUp.
Spoke in front of 500-600 educators about the importance of a successful support system for students.
